claim: Trump know the fact that the Clintons have murdered people.

supporting.text: There is no publicly available evidence or legal finding that supports the claim that the Clintons have murdered people.

attacks.text: There is no publicly available evidence or legal finding that supports the claim that the Clintons have murdered people.
Conspiracy theories and unverified claims have circulated for years suggesting the Clintons were involved in suspicious deaths.
Conspiracy theories lack credible evidence and are often based on speculation rather than verifiable facts.
Some individuals connected to the Clintons have died under unusual circumstances, raising suspicions.
Investigations into these deaths have not found any credible link to the Clintons, and many were due to natural causes or accidents.

supporting.text: Conspiracy theories alleging criminal behavior by the Clintons have been widely debunked by mainstream media and fact-checking organizations.

attacks.text: Conspiracy theories alleging criminal behavior by the Clintons have been widely debunked by mainstream media and fact-checking organizations.
Mainstream media and fact-checking organizations have been accused of bias and may not always provide impartial assessments.
Independent investigations and bipartisan sources have also found no credible evidence to support these conspiracy theories.
Some individuals and groups continue to promote these theories despite the lack of evidence, often for political motives.

supporting.text: No court of law has ever convicted the Clintons of murder or any related crime, which would be necessary to substantiate such a claim.

attacks.text: No court of law has ever convicted the Clintons of murder or any related crime, which would be necessary to substantiate such a claim.
Legal acquittal does not necessarily imply factual innocence, as some crimes may go unprosecuted due to lack of evidence or political influence.
The absence of prosecution or conviction in a court of law is the standard by which society determines factual claims, and speculation without evidence undermines legal principles.
There are credible allegations and circumstantial evidence linking the Clintons to suspicious deaths, even if not proven in court.
Circumstantial evidence and allegations without formal legal scrutiny are insufficient to establish factual claims, as they lack rigorous validation.

supporting.text: Public figures, including Donald Trump, have made unsubstantiated claims about the Clintons without providing verifiable evidence.

attacks.text: Public figures, including Donald Trump, have made unsubstantiated claims about the Clintons without providing verifiable evidence.
Some claims made by Trump about the Clintons have been supported by circumstantial evidence or witness testimonies, though not conclusive proof.
Circumstantial evidence and witness testimonies are often unreliable and can be influenced by bias or external pressures.
There have been investigations into the Clintons, such as the Whitewater controversy, which some argue indicate suspicious behavior.
Investigations like Whitewater did not result in convictions or conclusive findings of criminal activity by the Clintons.

supporting.text: Law enforcement and investigative agencies have not found credible evidence linking the Clintons to any murders.

attacks.text: Law enforcement and investigative agencies have not found credible evidence linking the Clintons to any murders.
Some independent investigators and whistleblowers claim to have evidence of suspicious deaths linked to the Clintons, though their claims are often dismissed by mainstream authorities.
Mainstream authorities and fact-checkers have debunked many of these independent claims as conspiracy theories lacking verifiable evidence.
Conspiracy theorists argue that mainstream authorities may be compromised or unwilling to investigate powerful figures like the Clintons.
